body.header: Look at the bar charts and complete the report by filling each gap with the correct tense of the verb given in brackets.
body.section:
A number of significant changes (take place) in the proportion of single-person households in England in recent years. Generally speaking, since 1971 there (be) a marked upward trend in the numbers of people living alone among the under 65s and this trend (be) most pronounced for men. In 1971 only about 3.5 per cent of households (consist) of one man living alone. By 2001 this figure (shoot up) to over 10 per cent. It is predicted that by 2021 the proportion (reach) almost 14 per cent of all households. A similar trend can be seen for women under 65. In 1971 women living alone (account for) just under 5 per cent of all households. By 2001 the proportion (rise) to around 7 per cent. Again, it is predicted that this upward trend (continue) for the foreseeable future. The pattern for the over 65s who live alone is somewhat different. Since the early 1970s the proportion of households consisting of male pensioners living alone (rise) steadily, but at a much slower rate than other types of single-person households. By 2021 almost 1 in 20 households (consist) of one man over 65. The proportion of female pensioners living alone (change) significantly in recent years. This used to be the most common kind of single-person household. In 1981, for example, this (account for) around 1 in 10 of all households. Since then, however, the proportion (fall) and it (decline) further over the coming years.
